document.ModsDocTitle: “High Tide or Low Tide”: Desisbobmarleyi sp. n., a new spider from coral reefs in Australia’s Sunshine State and its relative from Sāmoa (Araneae, Desidae, Desis)
document.docAuthor: Baehr, Barbara C., Raven, Robert & Harms, Danilo
document.masterDocTitle: " High Tide or Low Tide ": Desisbobmarleyi sp. n., a new spider from coral reefs in Australia's Sunshine State and its relative from Samoa (Araneae, Desidae, Desis)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: " High Tide or Low Tide ": Desisbobmarleyi sp. n., a new spider from coral reefs in Australia's Sunshine State and its relative from Samoa (Araneae, Desidae, Desis)

subSubSection.paragraph: Desis vorax L. Koch, 1872 Figures 6 A-F , 7E, F
169 Desis vorax L. Koch, 1872, 345-346, Taf. 29 fig. 1-1, Samoa-Inseln , Upolu, male Holotype (Mus. GODEFFROY Nr. 6538) (32) ( Rack 1961 ).
MALE HOLOTYPE (ZMH-A0000099), from The Independent State of Samoa , Upolu, 20°15'N , 155°51'W , Godeffroy Collection.

Males of D. vorax can be separated from other Desis species, including D. bobmarleyi , D. marina and D. kenyonae , by having a slim, triangular conductor plate (CP) and a slender conductor tip (Fig. 7F).

caption.paragraph: Figure 6. Desis vorax L. Koch, 1872, male holotype (ZSMH- A0000099): A, habitus, dorsal view; B, same, ventral view; C, prosoma, ventral view; D, male palp, retrolateral view; D, same, ventral view; E, same, prolateral view;. Scale bars: 1.0 mm.

Figure 7. Desis : A-D , Desis bobmarleyi sp. n., male holotype (QM S107379), female allotype (QM S107380) A, palp, retrolateral view; B, palp, ventral view; C, epigyne, ventral view; D, epigyne, dorsal view, cleared; E, F, Desis vorax L. Koch, 1872, male holotype (ZSMH- A0000099): E, palp, retrolateral view; F, palp ventral view; G, Desis formidabilis (O. Pickard-Cambridge, 1891), SEM, palp, ventral view (ex. Griswold et al., 2005 , fig. 177 B). Abbreviations: C, conductor; CP, conductor plate; DTA, distal tegular apophysis; E, emblus; MTA, median tegular apophysis. Scale bars: palps 1.0 mm, epigyne 0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Currently known only from Upolu, one of the islands of the Independent State of Samoa . The wider distribution of this species is still unknown but it may be more widespread across the islands of Samoa .
Apparently, this species has not been re-collected since its original discovery but may have been overlooked because it is found in habitats that are not usually associated with spiders.
